title: Social Interactions: Offering, Inviting, Apologizing, Gifting

content.text: In Darija, to make a basic offer or ask if someone wants something, you often use forms of the verb 'بغى' (bgha - to want). The most common phrase is 'واش بغيتي؟' (Wash bghiti?) which is versatile for both male and female singular. For a more direct 'Are you wanting (now)?', you can use 'باغي؟' (baghi?) for a male and 'باغية؟' (baghya?) for a female. For a group, use 'واش بغيتوا؟' (Wash bghitou?).

examples.english: Do you want coffee? (singular, m/f)
Are you wanting something? (to a male)
Are you wanting some help? (to a female)
Do you want to sit? (to a group)

content.text: To formally invite someone in Darija, you can use the phrase 'كنْعْرضْ عليكْ' (kan3rd 3lik). This phrase is used for both male and female singular. For inviting a group, you use 'كنْعْرضْ عليكمْ' (kan3rd 3likom). It literally means 'I offer to you' or 'I invite you'.

examples.english: I invite you to lunch tomorrow. (to a male/female)
I invite you (all) to the party.

title.english: Offering Food or Drink: Have some!

content.text: When offering food or drink, you can use the imperative verbs 'كُلْ' (kul - eat) and 'شْرَبْ' (shreb - drink). Remember to adjust for gender and number: 'كُلِي' (kuli) and 'شْرْبِي' (shrebi) for a female, and 'كُلُوا' (kulou) and 'شْرْبُوا' (shrebu) for a group. These are direct and polite ways to encourage someone to partake.

examples.english: Eat this tagine. (to a male)
Drink the juice. (to a female)
Eat some sweets. (to a group)

sentence.english: Do you want some juice? (to a male)

steps.context: Asking a male if he wants juice.

steps.question: Which phrase means 'Do you want?' when addressing a female?
steps.explanation: 'واش باغية؟' is used for asking a female if she wants something. 'واش باغي؟' is for a male, and 'واش بغيتوا؟' is for a group.

steps.question: Complete the sentence: '___ (I invite you, to a female) to my house.'
steps.explanation: The phrase 'كنْعْرضْ عليكِ' is used when inviting a female. Although 'عليك' is often written the same for m/f in Darija, in this context, the intent is for a female.

steps.question: How do you tell a group of people to 'Drink some'?
steps.explanation: 'شْرْبُوا' is the plural imperative form of 'to drink'.

title.english: Accepting Offers and Invitations: Yes, thank you

content.text: To accept an offer or invitation politely in Darija, you can simply say 'إيه، شكراً' (Ih, shukran - Yes, thank you) or 'واخا، شكراً' (Wakha, shukran - Okay, thank you). If you want to express more enthusiasm, you can add 'بكل فرح' (Bi koul farh - With pleasure).

examples.english: Yes, thank you, I will come.
Okay, thank you for the invitation.
With pleasure, I'd like this.
examples.transliteration: Bi koul farh, bghit had shshi.

content.text: Declining an offer or invitation politely is crucial. The most common phrase is 'لا، شكراً' (La, shukran - No, thank you). You can add 'بَارك الله وفيكْ' (Barak Allahu fik - May God bless you) to express gratitude, which is very polite. If you want to suggest another time, say 'مرة أخرى إن شاء الله' (Marra okhra insha'allah - Another time, God willing).

examples.english: No, thank you, may God bless you.
No, thank you, I'm full.
Another time, God willing.

title.english: Insisting on an Offer/Invitation: You must!

content.text: Moroccan culture often involves insisting when making an offer or invitation. Phrases like 'بْشْحَالْ ما كُلِّيتيشْ!' (Bshhal ma kllitish! - 'You haven't eaten in ages!', often used humorously to insist on food) are common. More directly, to insist someone come, you say 'خَصَّكْ تجي!' (Khassek tji! - You must come!) for a singular male/female, and 'خَصَّكُمْ تجيوا!' (Khassekoum tjiw! - You must come!) for a group. 'مْسْتْحيلْ!' (Moustahil! - Impossible!) can also be used playfully to insist on refusal.

examples.english: You haven't eaten in ages! Eat a little. (to a male)
You must come to our place for dinner. (to a female)
It's impossible for you (all) not to come.

sentence.english: No, thank you, I have to go now.

steps.context: Politly declining and giving a reason.

steps.question: What is a polite way to accept an invitation?
steps.explanation: 'إيه، شكراً' is a simple and polite way to accept.

steps.question: Choose the best polite phrase to decline an offer: 'No, thank you, ___.'
steps.explanation: 'بَارك الله وفيكَ' is a very polite way to express gratitude when declining.

steps.question: Which phrase means 'You must come!' (to a group of people)?
steps.explanation: 'خَصَّكُمْ تجيوا!' uses the plural form of 'you' and the plural imperative for 'to come'.

content.text: To apologize in Darija, you use forms of 'سمح' (smaḥ - to forgive/excuse). For a male, say 'سْمَحْ لِي' (Smeḥ li). For a female, say 'سْمْحِي لِي' (Smḥi li). For a group, it's 'سْمْحُوا لِي' (Smḥou li). These translate to 'Excuse me' or 'I'm sorry'. 'عْفَاكْ' (3fak - please/excuse me) can also be used for minor apologies or requests.

examples.english: I'm sorry, I'm late. (to a male)
I'm sorry for the mistake. (to a female)
Excuse me, may I pass?

title.english: Accepting an Apology: It's okay/No problem

content.text: When someone apologizes, you can respond with 'ماشي مشكل' (Machi mochkil - No problem). Another common phrase is 'لاباس' (Labas - It's okay/Fine), which can also mean 'how are you?'. For more serious apologies, 'الله يسامحْ' (Allah ysameḥ - May God forgive) is a respectful response.

examples.english: No problem, forget about it. (to a male)
It's okay, there's nothing (to worry about).
May God forgive, we all make mistakes.

title.english: Reassuring After an Apology: Don't worry about it

content.text: To reassure someone after they've apologized, you can say 'مَتْخافْشْ' (Matkhafsh - Don't worry) for a male, or 'مَتْخافِيشْ' (Matkhafîsh) for a female. A common and very idiomatic phrase is 'مَدِّيرْشْ فْ بَالَكْ' (Maddirch f balek - Don't put it in your mind) for a male, and 'مَدِّيرِيشْ فْ بَالَكْ' (Maddîrîsh f balek) for a female.

examples.english: Don't worry, everything went well. (to a male)

examples.arabic: مَدِّيرِيشْ فْ بَالَكْ، هادْ الشِّي عادي.
examples.english: Don't worry about it, this is normal. (to a female)
Alright, forget the subject. (to a male)

sentence.english: I'm sorry for the delay. (to a female)

steps.context: A female apologizing for being late.

sentence.english: No problem, don't worry. (to a male)

steps.context: Reassuring a male after his apology.

steps.question: How would a female apologize to someone?
steps.explanation: 'سْمْحِي لِي' is the correct form for a female to apologize.

steps.question: Complete the phrase for accepting an apology: '___ (No problem), it's okay.'
steps.explanation: 'ماشي مشكل' is a common and versatile way to accept an apology.

steps.question: What is a common way to reassure someone (female) after they apologize?
steps.explanation: 'مَتْخافِيشْ' is the female form of 'don't worry'. 'مَدِّيرْشْ فْ بَالَكْ' is for a male.

title.english: Asking About Gift Preferences: What do you like?
title.arabic: السؤال عن تفضيلات الهدايا: آش كاتبغي؟

content.text: When thinking about a gift, you might want to subtly ask about preferences. 'آش بْغِيتي؟' (Ash bghiti?) means 'What do you want?' and can be used for both genders. For a more general 'What do you like/prefer?', use 'آش كاتبغي؟' (Ash katbghi?) for singular (m/f) and 'آش كاتبغيو؟' (Ash katbghiw?) for plural.

examples.english: What do you want for your birthday? (to a male/female)
What kind of books do you like? (to a male/female)
What do you (all) like as a gift?

title.english: Suggesting a Gift Idea: How about...?
title.arabic: اقتراح فكرة هدية: آش بان ليك فـ...؟

content.text: To suggest a gift idea, a common phrase is 'آش بَانْ لِكْ فـ...؟' (Ash ban lik f...? - What do you think of...?). This can be used for both male and female singular. You can also use 'شْنُو رَايَكْ فـ...؟' (Shnou ra'yak f...? - What's your opinion on...?) for a male, or 'شْنُو رَايْكِ فـ...؟' (Shnou ra'y ki f...?) for a female.

examples.english: What do you think of a book?

examples.arabic: شْنُو رَايَكْ فْ ساعة جديدة لِيهْ؟
examples.english: What's your opinion on a new watch for him? (to a male)
examples.transliteration: Shnou ra'yak f sa'a jdida lih?

examples.arabic: شْنُو رَايْكِ فْ شي عْطرْ ليها؟
examples.english: What's your opinion on some perfume for her? (to a female)
examples.transliteration: Shnou ra'y ki f shi 'aṭr liha?

title.english: Presenting a Gift: This is for you

content.text: When giving a gift, you can say 'هادْ الشِّي لِيكْ' (Had shshi lik - This thing is for you). If the gift is a feminine noun, you might say 'هادِي لِيكْ' (Hadi lik - This (f) is for you). If it's a masculine noun, 'هادا لِيكْ' (Hada lik - This (m) is for you). You can also simply say 'مَرْحْبَا' (Marhaba - Here you go/Welcome) as you hand over the gift.

examples.english: This is for you, I hope you like it. (neutral gift)
This (bouquet) is for you, because you like roses. (feminine gift, e.g. وْرْدة)
This (phone) is for you, to your health! (masculine gift, e.g. تِّليفون)

sentence.english: What colors do you like? (to a female)

steps.context: Asking a female about her preferred colors for a gift.

sentence.arabic: آش بَانْ لِكْ فْ شي قميجة جديدة؟
sentence.english: What do you think of a new shirt?
sentence.transliteration: Ash ban lik f shi qamija jdida?

steps.context: Suggesting a shirt as a gift.

steps.question: How do you ask a female 'What do you like?' (general preference)?
steps.explanation: 'آش كاتبغي؟' is used for 'what do you like/prefer?' for both male and female singular. 'آش باغي؟' is for male 'what are you wanting now?'.

steps.question: Complete the sentence: '___ (What's your opinion) about this book?' (to a male)
steps.explanation: 'شْنُو رَايَكْ' is used to ask for a male's opinion.

steps.question: You are giving a wallet (صاك - masculine noun) as a gift to a friend. How do you say 'This is for you'?
steps.explanation: 'هادا لِيكْ' is used when referring to a masculine object like 'صاك' (saq - wallet/bag). 'هادْ الشِّي لِيكْ' is general, and 'هادِي لِيكْ' is for feminine objects.

title.english: Expressing Gratitude for a Gift: Thank you very much
title.arabic: التعبير عن الشكر على هدية: شكراً بزاف

content.text: When receiving a gift, it's customary to express strong gratitude. 'شكراً بْزَّافْ' (Shukran bzaf - Thank you very much) is very common. You can also use 'الله يْخَلِّيكْ' (Allah ikhellik - May God keep you), which is a deeply felt expression of thanks. To show how happy you are, you can say 'فرحتيني بْزَّافْ' (Farraḥtini bzaf - You made me very happy) (for both male/female giver).

examples.english: Thank you very much for the beautiful gift.
May God keep you, I liked it very much. (for a masculine gift)
You made me very happy with this surprise.

title.arabic: الرد على الشكر: لا شكر على واجب

content.text: When someone thanks you for a gift, there are several ways to respond. 'لا شُكْرَ على وَاجِبْ' (La shukra 'ala wajib - No thanks for a duty) is a more formal, humble response. 'مَرْحْبَا' (Marhaba - You're welcome) is common and friendly. Additionally, 'بْصِّحْتَكْ' (Bssehtek - To your health) is frequently used when someone receives something new, implying 'enjoy it in good health'.

examples.english: You're welcome. (formal)
You're welcome, enjoy it in good health.
Just accept it from me. (informal, modest)

title.english: Complimenting a Gift: It's beautiful/I love it

content.text: To compliment a gift, use 'زْوِينْ' (Zwin - beautiful/nice) for masculine nouns and 'زْوِينَة' (Zwina) for feminine nouns. To express that you like it, use 'عْجْبَنِي' ('ajbni - I liked it) for masculine objects and 'عْجْبَاتْنِي' ('ajbatni) for feminine objects. You can add 'بْزَّافْ' (bzaf - very much) for emphasis. 'هادْ الشِّي رائعْ' (Had shshi ra'i3 - This is wonderful) is a general compliment.

examples.english: The shirt is very beautiful, I liked it. (shirt is feminine - قميجة)
This book is beautiful, I liked it very much. (book is masculine - كتاب)
This is wonderful, thank you very much.

sentence.english: May God keep you, the gift is perfect (in its place).

steps.context: Expressing deep gratitude and satisfaction with a gift.

sentence.english: You're welcome, enjoy your new phone in good health.

steps.context: Responding to thanks for a new phone.

steps.question: What is a common way to say 'Thank you very much' for a gift?
steps.explanation: 'شكراً بْزَّافْ' is the most direct and common way to say 'thank you very much'.

steps.question: Complete the response to 'Thank you for the gift': '___ (You're welcome).'
steps.explanation: 'مَرْحْبَا' is a friendly and common way to say 'you're welcome'.

steps.question: You received a new watch (ساعة - feminine noun) and want to say 'It's beautiful!' How do you say it?
steps.explanation: Since 'ساعة' (sa'a - watch) is a feminine noun, you use the feminine adjective 'زْوِينَة' (zwina).
